Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A mechanistic test of the keystone mutualism hypothesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate how ecological interactions among caterpillars, treehoppers, and ants determine the health trees. Caterpillars damage forest trees by eating leaves and treehoppers feed on trees by sucking sap. An important consequence of sap-feeding by treehoppers is their excretion of a sugary solution called honeydew. Some forest-dwelling ants depend on the honeydew for food. This relationship is called a food-for-protection mutualism because ants receive carbohydrate-rich food, while treehoppers receive protection from predators by the ants. In this project, investigators will study how this interaction between ants and treehoppers affects all participants, and how the outcome impacts forest health.

Societal benefits of this project are several-fold. First, results from the research will contribute to the scientific understanding of pest control in forests. Second, the project will contribute to education about forest ecology and entomology through the training of undergraduate research assistants, as well as through broader educational benefits to college students, public school teachers, and members of the public. Third, the investigators will partner with the Connecticut Forest and Park Association (CFPA), which offers outdoor education programs for teachers and members of the public.

More specifically, this research will experimentally test several hypothesized mechanisms for top-down trophic effects of ant-sap-feeder mutualisms in a temperate forest community. This system contains multiple species of predatory ants interacting with sap-feeding insects (mainly Membracidae). Ant-sap-feeder mutualisms may trigger top-down trophic effects on caterpillars and plants via increases in total ant abundance (the "density increase hypothesis"), changes in the behavior of individual ants (the "behavioral modification hypothesis"), or changes in ant community structure (the "community shift hypothesis"). Experiments will be used to distinguish among these hypotheses. The community scope of this study system, which currently lacks an invasive ant species, is novel and important because it offers an opportunity to test ant-community mechanisms for keystone mutualism effects as well as ant density- and ant trait-related mechanisms in a relatively intact ecosystem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
By virtue of their great abundance and ecological versatility, ants are major players in terrestrial ecosystems. Their relationships with plant-feeding insects capture their ecological versatility because ants can engage in mutualistic symbioses with sap-feeding insects, such as treehoppers, while preying on leaf-chewing insects, such as caterpillars. This dualism makes it difficult to predict the broader ecological impacts of ants. For example, do the predatory effects of ants on caterpillars outweigh their facilitative effects on aphids and treehoppers, such that plants receive a net indirect benefit? Or does ant predation on leaf-chewing herbivores pale in comparison to their positive effects on sap-feeding herbivores, thus causing a net cost to plants? How does the mutualism between ants and sap-feeding insects affect the predator-prey relationship between ants and leaf-chewing insects? Other ecologists have identified this dilemma in ecological theory and have called for more research to address it. Our work has focused on this question in the oak-hickory forests of the northeastern U.S., which are both ecologically and economically important.

Prior to the start of this project, we showed that ant predation on caterpillars typically increased in the presence of sap-feeding insects. Therefore, our project goal was to test three hypothetical mechanisms that could explain this finding. We also sought to determine the consequences of these mechanisms for caterpillars, herbivory, and tree growth. These mechanisms are: 1) density increase hypothesis: sap-feeders recruit ants to host plants, increasing the total number of predators, thus increasing predation on caterpillars; 2) behavior modification hypothesis: sap-feeding herbivores alter ant behavior, increasing the per capita (ant) predation rate on caterpillars; and 3) community shift hypothesis: sap-feeders recruit ant species which are more likely to capture caterpillar prey.

We tested these hypotheses with a series of four field experiments on hickory trees, which frequently harbor sap-feeding insects such as treehoppers. The evidence from these experiments supports the community shift hypothesis, but not the density increase or behavior modification hypotheses. We found that sap-feeding herbivores strengthen the predatory effects of ants by altering the composition of ant species on hickory trees, but not by altering ant density or ant predatory behavior. Sap-feeders primarily recruited large-bodied carpenter ants, which were stronger predators of caterpillars and more aggressive towards prey and competitors. Overall, these experiments demonstrate an important role of carpenter ants in suppressing damaging herbivores of hickory trees in northeastern U.S. forests, that mutualistic sap-feeding insects mediate the effects of predatory ants, and that changes in ant community structure have consequences for tree-feeding herbivores. Ants reduced the abundance of leaf-chewing caterpillars in short-term experiments, and in long-term experiments, ants suppressed damage by twig-girdling cerambycid beetles on hickory saplings.

As part of this project, PI Clark participated in multiple relevant outreach programs to share knowledge of insect food webs, and ant and caterpillar biology. These included two bioblitz events (biodiversity surveys that display their results and biodiversity science to the public), two outreach events on caterpillar biology with elementary school students, four programs with the Connecticut Forest and Park Association on the role of insects in forest food webs, speaking engagements at two conferences on public involvement in local entomology and ecology, and an invited talk for a Connecticut land trust.
